questions.text: RBC uses which of the following substances during fasting/Starvation?
questions.solution:
Glucose Is Always Required by the Central Nervous System and Erythrocytes

Erythrocytes lack mitochondria and hence are wholly reliant on (anaerobic) glycolysis and the pentose phosphate pathway at all times.

The brain can metabolize ketone bodies to meet about 20% of its energy requirements; the remainder must be supplied by glucose. The metabolic changes that occur in the fasting state and starvation serve to preserve glucose and the body’s limited glycogen reserves for use by the brain and red blood cells, and to provide alternative metabolic fuels for other tissues.

So Option A is the correct option.

Targeted Gene Regulation by Disruption or Knockout, Knockin, Editing, and Controlled Expression

Various technical advances have allowed for the precise, targeted modification of mammalian genes. The exact methods used for genetically engineering mammalian genomes have evolved from tedious, low-efficiency methods based on positive and negative drug selections and homologous recombination (Knockout/Knockin) to the recently described CRISPR-Cas9 system. The goal of all of these methods is ultimately to generate a family of genetic variants of a gene of interest that are (a) a null, or complete loss-of-function allele; (b) recessive, loss-of-function alleles; and (c) ideally, dominant gain-of-function alleles. These genetic alterations are generated in pluripotent stem cells, which ultimately allow for introduction and propagation in whole model organisms (flys, fish, worms, rodents, etc). Having all three of these genetic variants allows one to precisely dissect the mechanism of action of any gene. However, complicating genetic analyses of many genes is the fact that their function(s) are essential for viability. To get around this problem, cell-type or tissue-specific genetic variants must be generated. This hurdle has been overcome through the use of cell- and tissue-specific enhancers that can drive the conditional (ie, experimentally controlled) expression of the targeting recombinases (ie, CRE-lox) and/or or nuclease (CRISPR-Cas9) that generate the altered genes, either null or loss- or gain-of-function alleles.

Alternatively, selected loss-of-function alleles can be generated through equivalent siRNA expression to knock down production of a specific gene product. Collectively, these methods allow for sophisticated genetic and biochemical tests of gene function and allow scientists to probe the structure and function of mammalian genes in physiologic contexts. Tremendous molecular mechanistic insights have been, and will continue to be, obtained into the molecular etiology of human disease through these and other biochemical approaches.

So option B is correct.

questions.text: Methyl tetrahydrofolate accumulation and functional deficiency of folate is seen in the deficiency of:
questions.solution:
Vitamin B12 Deficiency Causes Functional Folate Deficiency-the "Folate Trap"

When acting as a methyl donor, S-adenosyl methionine forms homocysteine, which may be remethylated by methyltetrahydrofolate catalyzed by methionine synthase, a vitamin B12-dependent enzyme.

As the reduction of methylenetetrahydrofolate to methyltetrahydrofolate is irreversible and the major source of tetrahydrofolate for tissues is methyltetrahydrofolate, the role of methionine synthase is vital, and provides a link between the functions of folate and vitamin B12. Impairment of methionine synthase in vitamin B12 deficiency results in the accumulation of methyltetrahydrofolate that cannot be used-the "folate trap." There is therefore functional deficiency of folate, secondary to the deficiency of vitamin B12.

So Option B is correct.

questions.text: Insulin inhibits which of the following lipase enzymes?
questions.solution:
Option A: The rate of release of FFA from adipose tissue is affected by hormone sensitive lipase that influences either the rate of esterification or the rate of lipolysis

Hormone-sensitive lipase is activated by ACTH, TSH, glucagon, epinephrine, norepinephrine, and vasopressin and inhibited by insulin, prostaglandin E1, and nicotinic acid.

Another principal action of insulin in adipose tissue is to inhibit the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase, reducing the release not only of FFA but also of glycerol. Adipose tissue is much more sensitive to insulin than many other tissues, and is thus a major site of insulin action in vivo.

Option B: Triacylglycerols of chylomicrons & vldl are hydrolyzed by lipoprotein lipase to form remnant lipoproteins. Lipoprotein lipase is an enzyme located on the walls of blood capillaries, anchored to the endothelium by negatively charged proteoglycan chains of heparan sulfate. It has been found in heart, adipose tissue, spleen, lung, renal medulla, aorta, diaphragm, and lactating mammary gland, although it is not active in adult liver. It is not normally found in blood; however, following injection of heparin, lipoprotein lipase is released from its heparan sulfate-binding sites into the circulation. Hepatic lipase is bound to the sinusoidal surface of liver cells and is also released by heparin.

Option C & Option D: Insulin has no effect on Acidic and alkaline lipase.

questions.text: Glycosylated HB (Hb-A1C) is best detected by:
questions.solution:
HbA1c is defined by the International Federation of Clinical Chemistry Working Group on HbA1c as the hemoglobin A that is irreversibly glycosylated at one or both N-terminal valines of the β-chains of the tetrameric hemoglobin molecule, including hemoglobin that may also (but not solely) be glycosylated on lysine residues.

HbA1c testing provides an index of average blood glucose levels over the past 2 to 4 months. Although the life span of red blood cells is approximately 120 days, HbA1c levels represent a “weighted” average of glucose levels, with the youngest erythrocytes contributing to a greater extent than older ones. Approximately 50% of the HbA1c level is determined by plasma glucose levels over the previous month and 75% during the previous 2 months.

Testing methods have been standardized to the HbA1c assay, which is now the preferred test to use to assess glycemic control. To avoid confusion for the general public, the American Diabetes Association, the American College of Endocrinology, and the National Diabetes Education Program recommend using the term A1c testing when referring to HbA1c equivalent (GHb) or HbA1c results. The National Glycohemoglobin Standardization Program (NGSP) began in 1996, with the goal of standardizing GHb tests to the high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) method reported as HbA1c or HbA1c equivalent, as used in the DCCT. Several types of certified methods are available for measuring hemoglobin A1c: immunoassay, ion exchange HPLC, electrophoresis, boronate affinity HPLC, and enzyme methods. Reliable benchtop point-of-care analyzers, such as the one that uses a cassette-based immunoassay method, also are available.

questions.text: Which of the following methods uses RNA
questions.solution:
Option A: In Western, blot, proteins are electrophoresed and transferred to special paper that avidly binds proteins and then probed with a specific antibody or other probe molecule. (Asterisks signify labeled probes, either radioactive or fluorescent.). It used to detect proteins.

Option B: PCR is a method of amplifying a target sequence of DNA by using cDNA.

For quantitative RNA analyses after RNA copying and mRNA quantitation done by RT PCR method (cDNA copies of mRNA generated by a retroviral reverse transcriptase), it uses RNA.

Option C: Sequencing of DNA by the chain termination method devised by Sanger. The manual enzymatic Sanger method employs specific dideoxynucleotides that terminate DNA strand synthesis at specific nucleotides as the strand is synthesized on purified single-stranded template DNA.

Option D: G banding (Giemsa banding) isa technique used in cytogenetics to produce visible karyotype by staining condensed chromosomes.

questions.text: Cytochrome C oxidase is inhibited by all except?
questions.solution:
Option A: Methane will not inhibit cytochrome c oxidase.

Option B, Option C & Option D: H2S, carbon monoxide (CO) and cyanide inhibit Complex IV and can therefore totally arrest respiration.

Cytochrome c oxidase is complex IV of electron transport chain.

Inhibitors of the respiratory chain provided knowledge about the mechanism of action of several poisons & drugs which are fatal at high dose.

questions.text: Binding site of miRNA on mRNA?
questions.solution:
The small ncRNAs termed miRNAs and siRNAs typically inhibit gene expression at the level of specific protein production by targeting mRNAs through one of several distinct mechanisms. miRNAs are generated by specific nucleolytic processing of the products of distinct genes/transcription units.

Following target mRNA location and sequence specific miRNA–mRNA annealing, the functional miRNA can modulate mRNA function by one of three mechanisms: translational repression, mRNA destabilization by mRNA deadenylation, or mRNA degradation.

Adenylated tail is present at the 3' end of mRNA, so the binding site of miRNA on mRNA is 3’ UTR of mRNA.

So Option B is correct.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes/diagnostic markers is incorrectly paired?
questions.solution:
Option A: Beta glucocerebrosidase is used as diagnosis of Gaucher’s disease, not Von Gierke’s disease. So it is incorrectly paired.

Option B: Ceruloplasmin level is used as a diagnostic marker of hepatolenticular degeneration.

Option C: High LDH1/LDH2 seen in myocardial infarction, can be used as a diagnostic marker.

Option D: Serum lipase level is increased in Pancreatitis, so used as a diagnostic marker of pancreatitis.

choices.text: Change in PH other than isoelectric PH

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for protein precipitation?
questions.solution:
The answer is: (A) Heavy metals

Heavy metals are not typically used for protein precipitation. They can be used to denature proteins, but they do not typically cause proteins to precipitate out of solution.

The other options are all commonly used for protein precipitation:

  • Alcohol and acetone are organic solvents that can disrupt the hydrophobic interactions that hold proteins together. This can cause proteins to precipitate out of solution.
  • Changes in pH can also cause proteins to precipitate out of solution. When the pH of a solution is changed, the charges on the surface of proteins can be altered. This can disrupt the interactions between proteins and cause them to precipitate out of solution.
  • Trichloroacetic acid (TCA) is a strong acid that can denature proteins. This can cause proteins to unfold and become more likely to precipitate out of solution.

choices.text: Decrease scavenging of RBC by macrophages

questions.text: What is seen in G6PD deficiency?
questions.solution:
Deficiency of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is an important cause of hemolytic anemia

The limited suite of metabolic pathways present in red blood cells renders them completely reliant on the pentose phosphate pathway or, to be more specific, the X-linked enzyme glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase for the reduction of NADP+ to NADPH.

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency is the most common of all enzymopathies (diseases caused by abnormalities of enzymes). More than 400 million people are estimated to carry one of the over 140 genetic variants of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase. This deficiency is most common among natives of tropical Africa (and their African-American descendants), the Mediterranean, and certain parts of Asia. Individuals harboring this deficiency are vulnerable to attacks of hemolytic anemia, a consequence of their inability to generate sufficient NADPH to maintain glutathione, a key intracellular antioxidant, in the reduced state.

Option A: In G6PD deficiency, peroxidative damage to lipids in the membrane also possible

Option B: In G6PD deficiency, decrease generation of reduced glutathione (GSH) from oxidized glutathione (GSSG) by glutathione reductase (which uses NADPH)

Option C: In G6PD deficiency, there will be decreased NADPH generation, not NADH.

Option D: In G6PD deficiency, increase scavenging of RBC by macrophages leads to hemolysis.

Mutations in the gene encoding enzyme ALA synthase cause X-linked Sideroblastic anemia. It leads to anemia with decreased red cell counts and hemoglobin.

Heme biosynthesis is initiated by the condensation of succinyl-CoA and glycine in a pyridoxal phosphate-dependent reaction catalyzed by mitochondrial δ-aminolevulinate synthase (ALA synthase.

Succinyl-CoA + glycine → δ-aminolevulinate + CoA-SH + CO2

Humans express two isozymes of ALA synthase. ALAS1 is ubiquitously expressed throughout the body, whereas ALAS2 is expressed in erythrocyte precursor cells. Formation of δ-aminolevulinate is rate-limiting for porphyrin biosynthesis in mammalian liver.

So Option A is correct.
